No. However, this depends on how one defines “really”? There is no doubt when we look at a clear sky during the day it will be blue. This is because the blue part of the spectrum is the wavelength most scattered by the atmosphere. Nonetheless, all colours are a product of our optical nervous system and don’t actually exist outside our minds. When we look up into the sky, all that actually exists is energy vibrating at a wavelength of about 500 nanometers. There is nothing about this wavelength to signify a particular colour. We just happen to have evolved to see this wavelength as blue. As we have gone our entire lives believing the sky is actually blue, this information is at first very difficult to digest. However essentially nothing has changed, other than a new perspective on something that requires deeper reflection. In reality a blue sky is an illusion created by our sensory awareness. Nonetheless, it is an illusion that aligns with the common human experience and therefore remains very useful. This is distinct from an hallucination, which doesn’t align with common experience and is often harmful. By understanding a blue sky is an illusion created by the mind, this is not implying the colour is artificial and therefore not beautiful. On the contrary, this is an understanding of the extraordinary power of our minds to create all the magnificent colours of a sunset. Then to project it out onto the canvas we call nature, to create unsurpassed beauty.
